plist.p: Thank you very much for that video, which is telling us about how MTN is transforming lives.

On behalf of MTN and the Board, led by our Chairman, Mr. Cyril Ramaphosa who is not here with us today, and the leadership of MTN led by our CEO, Mr. Sifiso Dabengwa, I wish to welcome you to our Interim Results for the Year Ending June 30, 2012. I also wish to welcome our colleagues who are watching us through various media channels across our operations.

Today's proceedings are fairly straightforward. Sorry, I think I pressed the wrong button here. Anyway, let me put this in. Today's proceedings are quite straightforward. First, we will have a strategic direction and input by our Group President and CEO and he will hand over to our Group Chief Financial Officer, Mr. Nazir Patel.

Later on we will allow you to ask questions. You should look for microphones on both ends of the hall. For members of the media we have time for you to interact with our CEO for about 15 minutes in Chard (01:32), which is one of the meeting rooms. For the members of the electronic media who would like to have some sound bites, there are three rooms which have been reserved for you, if we can meet you at about 11 o'clock when the President and CEO is finished.

Now, before I hand over to him, let me say that your BBMs and tweets and other social media platforms are welcome, but can you please bear with us by putting your phones on silent, so that our broadcast should be seamless and without any problems.
Can I now welcome our CEO and President, Mr. Sifiso Dabengwa?

Okay, thank you very much, Yuraisha, and very good morning to members of the Board, my colleagues and our fellow MTNers, wherever you may be, and ladies and gentlemen, very welcome and thank you very much for being with us this morning. I will just go through some of our key strategic issues and then go through some of the key aspects of our results. And then hand over to Nazir to go through the financials.

Looking at the strategic pillars of our business, we have identified the four areas as key to our business going forward. The creation of new value streams remains an important part of what we do, and we are continuing with a lot of work internally and in partnerships with others, looking at how we can find new revenue streams. Mobile Money and financial services continue to be a critical part of what we do and we hope to be able to significantly improve on the performance of Mobile Money during the course of this year and early next year, as we firmly believe that's an important part of our services.

From a value-creation point of view, we still continue to focus on shareholder return and continue to evaluate and pursue M&A opportunities and also want to maintain our position as an employer of choice, ensuring that whatever we do has long-term sustainability, driven by a strong performance-driven culture.

From a customer experience point of view, we have decided that strategically we need to be able to differentiate through excellent customer service and be able to position ourselves in our different markets very strongly, through customer experience, excellence (04:36) and focusing on making sure that we address the different market segments as per their requirements.

In terms of optimizing the business, leveraging on our scale and intellectual capacity is an important part of what we do and making sure that we optimize our cost base is also an important part of our activities. It is important and we firmly believe that it's important for us that in all our operating environments that we have the lowest cost structures in order to maintain and be able to compete effectively going forward.

Implementation of best practices is an important part of what we are doing and also focusing on the speed of execution, specifically on our strategic initiatives. As I indicated, customer experience will be central to all our activities, driven primarily by high-quality networks, efficient and wide distribution and supported by effective segmentation and strong customer analytics, with good, experienced people. And from a services point of view, we will still continue to provide voice and data services, comparatively priced, and also making sure that from a quality point of view we continue to be – offer the best in the different markets that we are in.

If we look at the value creation as part of our strategic considerations, we will continue our shareholder return strategy on dividends and buybacks, as we indicated previously. As far as dividends are concerned, our dividend payout ratio is to be increased to 72%, as a result of the STC removal and that keeps MTN in a cash-neutral, from an outflow position. During 2012 we bought back ZAR2 billion – just over ZAR2 billion worth of MTN shares and since we started the buyback program we have acquired just over ZAR3 billion of MTN shares.

From an M&A strategy point of view, nothing significant has changed. We are still focusing on local – broadening local ownership and also we are finding that we are having to find opportunities for shareholder value extraction, especially amongst the local shareholders.

We are still seeking consolidation for – sorry, we are looking for opportunities for in-country consolidation. We haven't been able to succeed in any, but it's something that we consider – we are spending a lot of time working on. The monetization of passive infrastructure through tower deals continues to be an important part of what we do. And in seeking licenses and acquiring additional spectrum is something that we continuously do and an important part of our strategy. And as far as spectrum acquisition is concerned, I will make some comments at a later stage.

As indicated before, Africa and Middle East remain core and an important part of our footprint. We still are looking for bolt-on standalone opportunities, and we – also we are looking at the number one or number two operators with meaningful scale and size. In terms of transformational opportunities, we believe that there really aren't too many at this stage and we always look at the execution risk as something to consider significantly.

Looking at the issue of revenue streams, voice continues to be an important part of our revenue stream. Airtime and subscription revenue is down to 63% of total revenue from 66% at the same time last year. We still continue to focus on maintaining and growing market and value share, as pressure on pricing leads to tariff decreases.

We've been able to successfully offer segmented and competitive offerings in most of our markets, and also the ability to distribute and drive low-cost handsets has been an important part of our strategy on growing voice. An important part of our strategy, obviously, is the issue of pricing in a manner than enables us to manage better the reality of multi-SIMs that we are seeing in most of our markets that are driven by promotions and short-term market share drivers by different players. And also we are seeing the fact that elasticity, it does have an impact on our network capacity requirements and therefore driving more CapEx.

From a data and related services, we've seen good growth across our business. Data now accounts for 10% of our revenue, up from 6% at the same time last year. Mobile Money subscribers are now at 7 million and we're now operating – we're providing the service in 13 countries. We do have a comprehensive device strategy, which we believe is very important in order to drive data services. Although in most countries other than in South Africa, we don't actually participate in distribution of handsets and devices. We have created very good and very strong relationships with local distributors to enable us to implement our data and our device strategies.

We continue to have a coordinated digital services priority, with partners and revenue-share arrangements. We have, as we indicated last year or early this year that we are looking at implementing platforms that can be shared across countries, in order to be able to deliver digital services. There is a strong focus on 3G capacity and coverage to support the growth in data and related services.

From an ICT perspective, we have recently reorganized the head office part, to streamline the ICT strategy to be managed under the Enterprise Business function and we continue to focus on the SME and the corporate segments and we also continue to make good progress in infrastructure investments to support ICT. As indicated previously, we are looking at ICT beyond mobile connectivity and we are focusing on cloud services for SME and corporates and also machine-to-machine services and we hope that by the end of this year, we should be in a position to start rolling out those services. A key part of our whole ICT strategy is that we intend to be delivering services that are based on utilizing the infrastructure that we already have that is based on mobile technologies.

In terms of business optimization, a very important part of our strategy has been the issue of cost optimization initiatives. The procurement initiative, which we started about 18 months ago and has progressed really well and up to about 45% of all our procurement, is now done centrally. We are in the process of establishing a single integrated supply chain team across the Group and we believe that that will enhance further our operational effectiveness and also improve on our ability to manage our suppliers.

We continue to grow in terms of shared IT services. The SEA IT hub is operating and continues to improve in terms of operational efficiencies. Uganda, Zambia and Swaziland are now operating from that hub. We hope that by the end of this year, Rwanda will also be included in that hub.

From an infrastructure sharing strategy, we have continued with our sale of towers. The sale of the Uganda towers has been completed. And earlier on this year, we initiated a program to look at back-office rationalization, which will focus on transactional activities in Human Resources, Finance and Supply Chain management. We will now have more shared facilities in order to deliver these back-office services. And we have continued, successfully in power cost reduction through the implementation of hybrid power systems and that's progressing very well.

Looking at the highlights of the business through June this year, subscribers are up 6.9% to 176 million; revenue, up 17.5% to ZAR66.426 billion and our EBITDA margin up to 44.9% and we're very pleased with that performance. Adjusted headline earnings per share, up 14% and the board has approved a dividend, interim dividend of ZAR0.321 per share. As indicated earlier on, the share buybacks for the six months through June has been to the value of ZAR2,088 million that's been completed.

Some of the key considerations for the period that we have just gone through, we have seen a very competitive landscape continuing from last year. We have seen aggressive price competition, which has been impacting traffic on the networks and also on the revenue. Traffic has not – we have not seen traffic growth – we have not seen revenue being compensated for by the traffic growth as elasticity has generally been below one. But we've also seen good growth, as far as data is concerned and that remains an important part of our business. CapEx implementation for increased voice and data implementation has gone reasonably well across most of our operations, although we have had and seen some challenges.

In terms of individual country backdrop issues, South Africa delivered very strong performance in a highly-penetrated market. So we're very satisfied with the performance across the board. Nigeria was impacted by aggressive price competition, also the reduction in fewer subsidies and lower than expected GDP performance. We've seen price stability in Ghana, Uganda, Iran and Cote d'Ivôire.

And then we've also seen continued ongoing socio-political unrest in Syria. As far as Yemen is concerned, the situation has improved but there are still some elements of instability. We are still having to manage ongoing UN, EU and U.S. sanctions against Iran and Syria. And we believe that we're managing these as best as we can. On July 2, this year, MTN filed a motion to dismiss the case filed against us by Turkcell in the U.S. and we are still awaiting the progress on that particular case.

Looking at individual countries and looking at them in terms of performance through June, as I indicated, South Africa performed very well, that we have seen the subscriber growth of 6.8% from December to 23.5 million subscribers and we've also seen ARPU slight decline to ZAR123 and minutes of use more or less stable from December at 68 minutes.

We've seen very strong prepaid growth, very good promotional campaigns and also supported by very good data offerings. We've seen good postpaid hybrid subscriber growth, up 25%. And we've seen very good indications in terms of value share trending positively. The interconnect rate was cut to ZAR0.56 in March and also the ARPU has been impacted by the traffic mix and increase in telemetry SIMs.

From a revenue point of view, airtime and subscription has gone up by 5.6%, driven by strong prepaid growth. Revenue generating minutes up 15.6%, interconnect down 15.3% and handset revenue up 29.1%, driven by good volumes on the postpaid and Smartphone volumes as well. Data revenue has gone up by 49%. The number of Smartphones has increased to 4.4 million on our network and the number of data users is now just below 12 million subscribers.

From an expense point of view, we have seen very good cost control and hence we have seen the EBITDA margin being managed to 35.4%. On-net traffic has increased from 60% to 65% and the higher handset cost due to depreciation of the rand is what we've had to deal with during the course of this period.

From a CapEx point of view there has been very good progress across the business and we've continued to focus on network modernization and also on self-providing. Focus also continued from a 3G coverage and a capacity point of view. The national long-distance projects have progressed very well after initial delays. We are still awaiting clarity on the process for the allocation of spectrum going forward and then also about 75% of the total authorized CapEx had been committed by the end of June. From a capitalization point of view, we have capitalized ZAR1.9 billion. As you can see, there's quite a significant improvement from last year at the same time.

Moving on to Nigeria, we ended Nigeria with a total market – with a total subscriber of 43,184,000, which was 3.7% growth from December last year. The market growth, as I indicated, was impacted by removal of fuel subsidies and generally lower consumption spending. We did experience in that market quite aggressive price competition during the first half and generally our pricing was at a premium of anything above 30% across the different offerings.

Our SIM offerings were probably not as competitive and as a direct result of that our gross acquisition were not as high as we would have liked. However, despite the loss of – or the slight loss of market share to 48%, we believe that form a value share point of view we have been able to maintain our value share. The SIM registration process is still very much continuing, and at this stage there's no indication when that will be terminated.

From a revenue point of view, interconnect revenue was up 11.5%, airtime and subscription down 4.4%, whilst the revenue generating minutes showed good growth of 28%. The effective tariff in this business really was significantly reduced by about 30% and hence the impact on the revenue growth. We've seen very good data growth albeit form a very small base, but we are very encouraged by what we have seen. We have 16 million active data users and 2.6 million Smartphones, and approximately 480,000 dongles.

From an expenses point of view, there's been good cost control overall in terms of the network operating cost and also there's been a reduction in commissions. On-net traffic – sorry, that's from the wrong one, sorry about that. The EBITDA margin in Nigeria has been impacted by the lower tariffs. The power costs are trending downwards as we increase the (24:32) and 2,312 sites have been completed using hybrid power systems. Transmission costs have significantly gone up as a direct result of data traffic and related costs. And interconnect costs have gone up by about 37%, as a result of increases in the off-net traffic.

In terms of CapEx, there's been really good progress overall, in terms of rolling out our CapEx plans. The focus has been on network quality, capacity and also expanding the 3G network. The 3G population coverage is now at 35% and we've now do have about 7,600 2G sites, with 2,600 3G co-located sites. We have continued to roll out fiber to support the data strategy and obviously to support the increases in voice traffic. A key part of what we have been focusing on is getting the transmissions bottleneck addressed and we believe that, as we go into the second half of the year that will be well underway.

And as at the end of June, 73% of the authorized CapEx had been committed. And again, from a capitalization point of view we have capitalized ZAR4.4 billion worth of CapEx, which is about twice what we had done at the same time last year.

Moving on to Ghana, very good performance overall, ending up with 10.7 million subscribers, very attractive market offerings and promotions. The market now has six strong operators. There has been a slight reduction in market share, but again, we believe that from the value share point of view, we have been able to maintain that. In terms of revenue, airtime and subscription revenue up 18%, interconnect up 11%. We've seen very strong data growth, but again from a low base. We now have 3.4 million data users and 987,000 Smartphones. Revenue generating minutes were up by 11% and we've seen a very stable market pricing situation in Ghana.

From an expenses point of view, the rent and utilities have gone up by 130% due to the leasing of the 400 towers. Distribution and commission costs have gone up as a direct result of volumes. Interconnect costs has also gone up due to the increase in off-net traffic and we expect the WACS landing station to be implemented and operational during the second half of this year and that will assist significantly in terms of data traffic. EBITDA margin performance has been pleasing at 37.7%.

Looking at it from a CapEx point of view, we've seen good improvement as far as capacity and quality of service is concerned. 3G coverage and capacity remains a priority. We're now covering about 38% of the population on 3G. There were minor delays earlier on this year. However 53% of the authorized CapEx has been committed.

Moving on to Iran, we have seen, again, excellent performance from our Iranian operation. We have increased our market share now to about 47%, very good promotional offerings and excellent network quality. The third mobile operator did launch during the first half of the year in two cities, and they do have exclusivity on 3G up until May, 2013. We've seen this uplift in local currency ARPU of about 7.7%. As at the end of June, the subscriber base has moved up to 38.296 million, which has been a really good achievement.

From a revenue point of view, airtime and subscription up by 25%, interconnect up by 13%, very good growth SMS revenue about 36%, strong data growth, including WiMax by 89%. We now have about 10.4 million data users. Total revenue-generating minutes up by 26% and we are seeing in the market that there's continuation of subsidy removals, but there are cash grants for the very low income groups.

From an expenses point of view, whilst Iran is a high inflationary environment, particularly driven by fuel, electricity and imported goods, we have managed to manage the cost base quite effectively. Lower distribution costs and commissions, as we have pushed for increases in logical distribution. We have seen an increase in data and value-added services costs as a result of revenue share, and also from a result of increased uses of the services.

From a CapEx point of view, the focus again is on improving quality and capacity and still on population and geographic coverage. We had a good performance as far as the rollout is concerned and 77% of the authorized CapEx had been committed by the end of June, which is again showing good progress on the management of our CapEx plans.

Syria is still very much impacted by the political unrest, which is impacting the economy and the ability to operate. Staff safety remains an important priority for us. The overall business performance is really underpinned by network reliability and airtime availability and our ability to maintain the network and get product out into the market.

The BOT conversion, which we have been discussing for the past 12 to 18 months, is clearly subject to the resolution of the political process. However, in terms of overall performance, we are quite satisfied that under the circumstances the business has performed reasonably well.

Market share has been held at 45% and we have seen a subscriber growth of about 3.3% since December 2011. From a revenue point of view, we have seen an airtime and a subscription increase of 8.8%, data up 39%. Pricing has been generally stable and we have seen revenue-generating minutes up 13%.

From an expenses point of view, we have experienced good cost control. Distribution and commission costs have gone up by about 36%. That's driven primarily by volume and also the use of our logical distribution to facilitate payments of postpaid bills, because this has and does carry commission costs and that has impacted that line. Fuel security and currency devaluation are the main cost drivers in this business at this moment in time.

From a CapEx point of view, the main focus really has been on the core modernization, very limited activities around increasing coverage or capacity. 81% of the authorized CapEx has already been committed, but also the fact that the political environment has caused some challenges as far as rolling out is concerned, but, at the same time, there really has been very limited damages to our infrastructure.
Then in terms of the other operations, generally we have seen very good performance Ivory Coast, Cameroon, Uganda and Sudan and we are satisfied with the overall performance.
I will now hand over to Nazir to just go through the financials. Thank you.

Thank you, Sifiso. Good morning to members of the audience, a special welcome to members of the MTN Group Board, members of the MTN Executive Committee and all to the MTNers listening to this webcast or participating in this presentation.

And as Sifiso noted, when we look at the six-month' results we see characteristics of a very strong underlying operating performance. But you should keep in mind that we had negative charges, both on the finance cost line, which increased quite significantly compared to the six-month period in 2011, as well as on the tax charge line, which I'll take you through in greater detail as we go through the rest of the presentation. These had a dilutive impact on the reported earnings per share for the six-month period.

But overall, we reported EBITDA margins which have grown quite – reasonably well to 44.9%, given the tough economic environment. Revenues on a reported basis have increased by 17%, which we believe is quite pleasing, given the underlying competition, of a heightened competition in many of the markets as Sifiso has taken you through as well as some very aggressive price competition in most of our key markets.

Measured on an organic basis, revenues come through at 13%, indicating some currency impacts of about 4%. We see much of the same as we get down to the EBITDA line, and I will take you through this in a bit more detail as we get through the rest of the presentation.

CapEx went pleasingly, it went up from ZAR5.7 billion to ZAR10 billion. It was a criticism of the Group that we generally trend to struggle to put CapEx into the ground. And what's important here is that at this stage, while we've capitalized ZAR10 billion of CapEx, a significant portion of the CapEx which we guided you at the first half – or the end – at the first half of the year has now been committed and I believe that number to be in the order of about 70%. Our CapEx-to-revenue, as a result, has increased about 15.3%.

We've also shown you the impact of operating margins and the evolution of that, it goes up by 0.2 point, from 43.8% to 44%. But keep in mind what we've done in that number is eliminated what we call one-time items and there are two here to keep in mind, which again we'll talk about later in the presentation.

One was the profit on the sale of the Ghana towers, which was concluded just before half year. That amount is ZAR547 million and for the accountants, just to show you that I do remember this one, there is an additional ZAR19 million of profit, which relates to the eliminated profit on the Ghana tower core transactions from last year, which are recognized over the 18 year period. So I hope the accountants are happy with that explanation.

Not surprisingly, given that more than 70% of the Group's performance is measured in currencies other than the South African rand, exchange rate volatility during any period plays a meaningful, or has a meaningful impact on our Group consolidated rand reported results. And if we look at the underlying six months and you look at the performance of key currencies, in the portfolio against the U.S. dollar, you'll find the real, the cedi and the rand depreciated in a range of 14% to 18%. And you can see the numbers quite clearly on the chart.

The Syrian pound, as a result of the political strife and upheaval in the country, has devalued quite markedly and it has had an impact, as you will see later on the finance cost line and on average rate basis compared to the first six months of last year has declined by about 36%.

Although, the Sudanese pound looks much more conservative in terms of devaluation, please keep in mind that late in the second quarter of 2012 we saw a very significant devaluation that was announced by the Reserve Bank of Sudan and that devaluation came through at approximately about 80%. So as we go through the rest of the year, we will find that will have a much more meaningful impact.

But clearly, as we move to consolidated rand results, what we should note here is the relatively muted devaluation of the naira versus the U.S. dollar of 4%, effectively translates into a gain in the rand exchange cross rate by about 10%. So whilst Nigeria revenues and EBITDA were relatively muted, even measured in rand terms when we translate those into – sorry, in naira terms, when we translate those into rand terms it look a lot more meaningful and we'll take you through those as well.

Again focusing on the revenue number, strong growth overall on a reported basis of 17%. That includes about a 4 point pickup or an impact, as a result of the foreign exchange movements of ZAR2.8 billion, which moves overall reported revenues to ZAR66 billion for the Group.

Underlying that when you look at the organic growth, we saw particularly strong growth coming through from – like South Africa, Iran, as well as Ghana as Sifiso has mentioned. If we look at the RSA numbers, that's reported as – following the change in the interconnect rate adjustment back in March last year.

If we had adjusted for those, the total South Africa revenues on a constant MTR (39:24) basis for 2011 would have been about 4 percentage points higher. So South Africa revenues would have grown by instead of 9.5%, a total of about 13%. That impact was about ZAR700 million dilutive to the interconnect revenue line.

South Africa, as Sifiso also mentioned, was pretty strong in terms of prepaid growth. Prepaid grew 15% compared to the six months in the prior year. And data remained extremely strong as well at 49%. And I think you have enough color on that one.

Nigeria, now keeping in mind of their – a few fundamental characteristics. While we've shown you earlier that airtime revenue actually declined 5.5%, this is in the backdrop of a fairly significant change in effective tariffs in the Nigerian market, most of which took place during 2011. And that effective tariff change was in the order of 30%, so it's not surprising, despite the additional subscribers that are coming in, you have to keep in mind that the entire value in the airtime market has actually been eroded. We saw similar things happening in Uganda about a year ago, which we've subsequently corrected. So clearly there's still some adjustment. The market is heavily punctuated by aggressive promotional activity, freebies, et cetera, which will continue to impact this number for some time to come.

The other point to note in Nigeria as well is based on some external research reports. We understand that that the actual level of consumer spending on communication services has declined by about 2% as a result of – and this is in comparison with the same period last year – as a result of the withdrawal of subsidies, which you're all aware of, took place very early in the first half of this particular year. So given that backdrop, I guess, Nigeria revenue growth of overall 4% coming through largely on a basis of higher interconnect revenues as well as a strong growth in data, which supports the overall great data strategy.

Iran, not too much to comment. Extremely strong growth of 28%, and it's based on very strong customer acquisitions coming through, which is also reflected in market share gains against the incumbent operator.

Ghana, very pleasingly continues to perform very well, and in fact, growing at a higher rate of revenue growth than we saw last year. Stabilized tariffs have helped, but clearly very well segmented value propositions into the market and well organized distribution strategy, et cetera, continue to drive value share in that market, as well as maintain our overall market share measured on a SIM basis of about 50%. So clearly a very good result for Ghana.

Syria has come in pleasingly at 12%, despite the pressures in the market, and whilst revenue growth in the first quarter was on the low side, we saw fairly strong revenue growth coming through at the end of the second quarter. And again as Sifiso mentioned, this was largely due to availability of the network for airtimes sales.

So looking at this more on a segmented basis, I think the key point to keep in mind here is the transition between what we call voice revenue growth as well as data revenue growth. It's not a surprise, as is noted elsewhere in the industry, that we see a slower rate of airtime revenue growth coming in whilst the airtime revenue on a nominal basis has grown from ZAR37 billion to almost ZAR42 billion. The rate of contribution to our total Group revenues has declined from 66% to 63%. Please keep in mind that these have not been adjusted for foreign currency effects.

As I noted, overall data growth has moved from ZAR3.9 billion to ZAR 6.7 billion, which is an overall growth of 70% and that number now contributes to about 10% – accounts for about 10% of total Group revenues. So it kind of sustains or at least justifies the entire investment in terms of data networks and obviously opens up further opportunity for growth as we go forward.

Mobile phones and accessories, although a lower number, has grown sharply by 28% year-on-year, and that's largely due to the increased volume of handsets as well as Smartphones going through the South African network, and to an extent, a higher rate of selling prices, as well.

Moving on to OpEx – and as Sifiso mentioned, we have a number of OpEx initiatives, and I think the key point to keep in mind here is, when you look at the margin evolution at an individual OpCo level, most of the change that we've seen on the lower side has come from the cost of sales lines. When you look at pure OpEx in the Group, it has remained extremely well under control as a result of all the cost initiatives that we put into place.

Not surprisingly, the biggest growth has come through areas like direct network operating costs as a result of the focus on network expansion in key countries like Nigeria and South Africa, as well as in selling and distribution costs as we're pursuing stronger customer acquisition initiatives as well as some higher commission costs coming through.

One point to reflect on in Nigeria, by way of example, which is something that we keep talking about, is the initiative to actually control the rate of diesel usage on the network seems to be paying off. At half year 2011, we advised you that the total diesel bill as a percentage of revenue was at 3.6%. That's now declined to about 3.3%, and that's despite about an 8.5% increase in the diesel price per liter. This is an important number because it justifies the investment in what we call the hybrid strategy. To date, just over 2,000 towers in Nigeria are now on the hybrid network – on the hybrid system, anyway.

Looking at EBITDA margins, pure operating margins have declined marginally by 0.2%, and most of that comes through from Nigeria, which accounted for about 0.8% dilution of the Group EBITDA margins. This is not including the FX impacts. Once we add all the FX impacts, which has a beneficial impact, the margin overall actually picks up by 0.2%, moving it up by – to 44%.

But we should take a moment and just talk about the Nigerian margin. The 2.8% reduction, which took place since June 2011 to the reported date now, is largely due to two or three items. One is a higher rate of interconnect cost as we pushed a lot of traffic off-net as well – and that number has moved down from 82% to roughly 81% in a bid to just counter the incoming traffic that was growing off other networks. That has an impact of about 1.7% negative impact on margin, comparing the six months this year to comparing the six months last year. And on a combined basis, increased commissions costs as well as higher SIM card costs accounted for another full point of the margin dilution.

Iran, very pleasingly, as a result of solid cost control, was able to lift up margins to 44.7%, bringing the total ZAR-related growth in nominal EBITDA for Iran to about 38%. The drop-through on a local currency level was at 36%, which is significantly higher than the revenue growth of 28%. Again, this shows you the value of good cost control, but also through some – a lot of the benefits coming through from the high revenue, while the costs were kept under control.
Ghana margins pleasingly towards the (46:28) 38%, and this is despite absorbing the costs related to leases for the Ghana towers, which now sit in Leap (46:37) joint venture.

Syria margins were down by about 2.5 points. We took a charge as a provision, which is related to international interconnect. It does not sit in the cost of sales line. It sits in pure OpEx. For a potential revision of the international interconnect rate, down from SYP4 to SYP1.

But very pleasingly, the dilution of the Nigerian margin was to a large extent offset by the combined effect of improvements that we saw in the South African margin by about 0.3%, the Iran margins, at least at Group level of 0.2%, from places like Sudan, which increased EBITDA margin performance year-on-year or half year-on-half year by 10%, Cote d'Ivôire by about 4% and Uganda by about 2.8%.

The Ugandan one was quite pleasing, given some of the tariff trauma we saw in the market back in (47:17 – 47:30) 2010 and 2011. So a lot of that margin recovery is coming through as a result of the higher revenue coming through in the operation, which is now growing at 30%-plus in more recent quarters. So overall, a very good story on margins for the Group.

As I noted earlier on the first slide, the pain that we've taken really relates to two items, one on the finance cost line and one on the tax line. Finance costs have increased by almost ZAR1.2 billion as a charge to income. The net interest paid line was much lower at ZAR6 million compared to the ZAR 775 million of year last year, and it was largely due to interest income on treasury bills and bonds that we have invested in Nigeria and one or two other countries.

ForEx losses, however, are really the key feature and they've increased by almost ZAR1.7 billion when comparing the current period to the six months of 2011.
